items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as heavy rain and thunderstorms are still forecast to affect the London area overnight into Thursday 18 August. While uncertainty remains around exact timings and which areas will experience the heaviest rain, it is possible that areas experiencing the heaviest showers will experience some flooding. River levels could rise quickly and overtop their banks, flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible. Surface water flooding may also impact areas affected by the heaviest showers. We recommend you monitor local weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation closely and have had staff out on the ground checking and clearing trash screens. We will update this message by 10am Thursday morning.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
No further flooding is expected, however there may be standing water seen in low lying areas. The weather forecast for the coming 5 days is largely dry, although a small risk of isolated showers still exists. We do not expect any flood impacts such as those experienced yesterday, Wednesday 17th August. 
We continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are on the ground clearing debris from rivers and working with local communities.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The risk of flooding from thunderstorms has now passed and no further rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.

We have seen heavy rainfall overnight in the River Rase and Ancholme catchment area. This means that the rivers are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the morning on Wednesday, 17 August onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout Wednesday. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated  as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from the watercourses around Harpers Brook to Willow Brook has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Bain, River Waring, Haltham Beck, Scrivelsby

items.message: Over the last 24 hours, we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Bain catchment area. This means that river levels are now rising, which may lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the evening of Wednesday, 17 August onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling and the risk of flooding to property has now reduced but the risk to road and low lying land remains.  The Flood Warning for the area has been removed but a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider catchment. Further thunder and rainfall is forecast this evening and drier conditions will resume tomorrow morning, Thursday 18th August. 
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and local councils.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further heavy rainfall which could cause impacts is forecast, although there may be showers over the next two days. 
We continue to monitor the situation.

Following heavy rainfall yesterday, the water level in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone is now slowly falling. At Sandown the level has just peaked, and will begin to fall later on this morning (18/8/22). Today, thunderstorms are no longer forecast, although lighter showers could bring small amounts of rain (up to 10mm). If any showers should impact the river, whilst the water level will rise a little, it will remain in bank. From tomorrow onwards (19/8/22) the weather is drier and settled and the water level in the river will return to normal.
